hedline.hl1: Metro Business; New York City Bonds Get Higher Rating

abstract.p: Standard & Poor's Corp raises New York City's bond rating to A, highest level since fiscal crisis of mid 70's; city says upgrades by company and Moody's Investors Service should save city millions of dollars a year (S)

block.p: New York City yesterday won another endorsement of its improved financial health when Standard & Poor's raised the city's bond rating to the highest level since the fiscal crisis of the mid 70's.

The new A rating, up from A-, is the second time Standard & Poor's has improved its rating of the city's bonds since 1998, but New York is still 8th among the nation's top 10 cities, according to Standard & Poor's. The improvement follows a similar upgrade last month by Moody's Investors Services.
New York City yesterday won another endorsement of its improved financial health when Standard & Poor's raised the city's bond rating to the highest level since the fiscal crisis of the mid 70's.

The new A rating, up from A-, is the second time Standard & Poor's has improved its rating of the city's bonds since 1998, but New York is still 8th among the nation's top 10 cities, according to Standard & Poor's. The improvement follows a similar upgrade last month by Moody's Investors Services.
''The city has made good progress in its financial management, and certainly the strength of the economy has helped,'' said Colleen Woodell, a director in public finance for Standard & Poor's.

City officials said yesterday the upgrades should save millions of dollars a year as a result of lower interest costs on money borrowed to pay for construction projects. The city is to offer about $425 million of tax-exempt debt securities for sale next week.
